text: <@U1A9JNB1T|karan> has joined the channel
<@U1BC5NF2S|bramwelt> has joined the channel
<@U14FUGATW|dan.mccarty> has joined the channel
<@U0N1D1UAE|bcbrock> has joined the channel
<@U1BC5NF2S>, <@U14FUGATW> <@U0N1D1UAE>  we should probably bring the discussion of Jenkins pipeline reaching out to alternate platforms here
<@U12V3D2P2> and Srirama Sharma (don’t know his handle) are the owners for build and CI on POWER
<@U12V3D2P2|bsmita> has joined the channel
Do these ‘workers’ have to be public? I don’t know how these jobs get kicked off. Can the workers be behind a firewall?
<@U11NUTP4L|srirama_sharma> has joined the channel
or <@U0KM61BCP> do we need to donate a machine to the Linux Foundation?
<@U0UHG4VP1|ry> has joined the channel
<@U0N1D1UAE>: I am not 100%, but I think if the jenkins setup itself is reasonably locked down, you can have a worker that isnt just open to the public
bcbrock: we usually set up a VPN to keep this stuff off the internet.
e.g. you can privately federate them with the security equal to the security of the overall jenkins config
if we could get an openpower box made available via softlayer or one of our partners, that would be good

for instance, we have builders at Azure that are only on the 10. network behind our VPN, which only allows traffic from our management network. I’m sure we can do something similar at where ever we end up with these resources, provided we can run a fairly stock Fedora VM with like 1 or 2 cores and maybe a gig of ram. The VPN box doesn’t require much.
by we I mean AllSeen Alliance, this other community project I work on for Linux Foundation.
<@U12V3D2P2> I’m thinking SuperVessel
This is an OpenPOWER cloud set up by IBM Research China
<@U0N1D1UAE>: won’t that introduce networking latencies that might tend to result in failures?
I thought that we also had some openpower boxen at some uni in the US… maybe Portland?
China has been problematic for us (LF) in the past. If we’re going to do something in China it would probably need to be self-contained
LF has a close relationship with OSU, if that helps.
<@U0KM61BCP>: Previous OSUOSL'er here. I can confirm you have resources at OSU. :wink:
Who is going to supply Linux for z systems?
<@U10Q62R8X>: is linuxone a solution here ^^^
<@U10Q62R8X|vpaprots> has joined the channel
<@U14FUGATW>:  wouldn't that be your team?
Maybe something from our team or from LinuxOne.
<@U0UHG4VP1> What is the opposite of self-contained? How does non-self-contained work?
I’never set up or really used any of these systems
<@U0N1D1UAE>: Zero access to our network.
(for self-contained)
bcbrock: we set up a VPN that all of the infra is on. the public facing infra (gerrit, jenkins) have a public interface and one on the private network.
we keep everything segregated east-west, so compromising one machine on one project doesn’t get you any closer to compromising other machines of the same type on other projects
north-south, within a CP, there is still a fair amount of containment. specific ports to and from specific classes of machines, etc
OK, the POWER team is meeting tomorrow, we’ll discuss these requirements
CP: collaborative project. <http://collabprojects.linuxfoundation.org/> for a list

attachments.title: Linux Foundation Collaborative Projects
attachments.text: With Linux Foundation Collaborative Projects we have one goal: to spread the collaborative DNA of Linux to new fields to enable innovation and access for all.

text: If I start fogging you out with internal LF jargon please tell me to knock it off
<@U0N1D1UAE>: thanks
<@U0UHG4VP1> <@U1BC5NF2S> what remains before we can start the transition from Travis?
<@U0KM61BCP>: Were working on getting fabric build on at least Ubuntu.
or Centos

<@U0KM61BCP>: here are the two larger items that will need to happen. 1) transition projects to gerrit <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/q/status:open> 2) get jobs in JJB that build HL. all other work items flow from those two.
<@U0KM61BCP>: I only see fabric on travis, but I saw mention of 'sawtooth'. Are there other hyperledger projects in Travis?
for sawtooth, Intel told me they were using Jenkins (internally) so they have stuff to migrate to an LF pipeline
for fabric, we have travis which the team will need to rework for jenkins, and we have some multi-arch stuff to do as well
cbf: here is the repo JJB YAML will come in to: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=summary>
for fabric-api, DAH has some jenkins, I believe that they need to refactor and bring over
I have been pushing jenkins since December since travis doesn't support z, or p.. nice to see when jenkins is the right choice for other reasons, and not just 'z'..
z or p?
ah, so gerritt is a pre-requisite?
Travis has been an excellent platform for open source testing, but the definitely have their limits.
cbf: not really. we can get jobs building from github to bootstrap.
<@U0UHG4VP1> Z/Linux is mainframe… p == openpower
I want to get Jenkins up-and-running and then transition to gerrit.

regarding z resources... I happen to be across the hall from the Node.js team on z.. we 'donated' three boxes, permanently alocated from LinuxONE public cloud, to google to run builds on.. this is similar in my mind..
<@U0KM61BCP>: you drive the CI WG, if you want to move everything to gerrit faster that’s OK but I’d rather have Jenkins replicating Travis results first
ok, I must have misread up above… thought I saw that step 1 was gerritt
that is a personal preference, not a technical preference.
agree getting jenkins builds stable should be first
it involves some hagling with the LinuxONE admins, but they are very helpful in my experience and have been trying to get MORE things blockchain onto their platform..
that was not an ordered list, sorry.
plus, I think that we should wait for after June for Gerritt
cbf: I’m rather belt-and-suspenders so I’d like to move slowly
what happens in june? another f2f?
ok, let’s focus on Jenkins then
by slowly I mean “don’t change everything at once"
not “I’d like to transition from Travis sometime in 2017” :slightly_smiling_face:
Is Ramesh or Barry on this channel? Them and Dan, have been working on Jenkins for a while now
actually, having the jenkins scripts in gerritt will help me (at least) get accustomed to gerritt
haven’t used in anger b4
just as passive observer for openstack reviews
<@U11HTMW0H|bmos299> has joined the channel
<@U11HH3P7Y|ramesh> has joined the channel
cbf: are you signed up for an LF account? can you log in to <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/login/%23%2Fq%2Fstatus%3Aopen> ? IIRC you do have an LFID
<@U11HH3P7Y> and <@U11HTMW0H> both on this channel, yes
<@U0UHG4VP1> yeppers
cbf: we’re using JJB so it’s YAML similar to: <http://docs.openstack.org/infra/jenkins-job-builder/>
<@U0UHG4VP1> <@U11HH3P7Y> we are working on setting up Jenkins and driving the agents.  Thanks for the link.
<@U11HTMW0H>: I hope that translates to setting up the scripts that will drive the same build test we have in travis? not sure what you mean by setting up jenkins

<@U0KM61BCP> standing up a jenkins server and driving agents to replicate the Travis CI work and also driver other platforms.  Once complete, we will work with the LF to port the work to the community.
why are you doing that? we have LF jenkins - please use that
It could be valuable if they’re using JJB.
<@U0KM61BCP>  <@U0UHG4VP1> Sure. Can I get the name of the LF contact who can give us access?  <@U11HH3P7Y> had made a lot of progress understanding Jenkins over the past week.
we are all here... <@U0UHG4VP1> and <@U1BC5NF2S> can get you and <@U11HH3P7Y> and anyone else added to the gettitt - see link above
<@U11HH3P7Y> has been using groovy with a pipeline project.
cbf: are you signed up for an LF account? can you log in to <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/login/%23%2Fq%2Fstatus%3Aopen> ? IIRC you do have an LFID
LF uses JJB
<@U0KM61BCP>: I don't have access to LF account.
they are free... <@U0UHG4VP1> can point you at registration
sign up here: <https://identity.linuxfoundation.org/>
thx
once you’re logged in to gerrit.hl.o check out the empty repo <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/admin/projects/lf-sandbox,branches> and we can walk through some basic gerrit workflow in the morning
for instructions: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/Documentation/index.html> section 1 in the tutorial will get you rolling
the biggest change is you’ll be doing this: git commit -s (sign) and then git push origin HEAD:refs/for/branch which will generate a review
read sections 1a and 1b. 1[cd] are not germane
cool... I will be mostly off-line due to obligations at CF Summit but please help <@U11HTMW0H> and <@U11HH3P7Y> at least get going
yes absolutely
I also suggested that STL start their migration from internal jenkjns
anyone with a properly set up LF account with SSH key added in gerrit should be able to push changes to the sandbox repo.
<@U1914JUPK|bernardlin> has joined the channel
<@U0ZLVCQPM|jkirke> has joined the channel
<@U0UHG4VP1>: I have registered an account. will go through the documentation. Thanks
<@U11HH3P7Y>: sure. this is async so feel free to ask questions as you have them
sure
ramesh: could you look at this: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/19/> when logged in, click reply, and tell me what options you see?
Code Review and verified
I could see these two
so a range of -1 0 +1?
yes
what is your exact LFID, with caps and everything
if you have time for shenanigans, if you don’t just say so. I’m on the west coast
rameshthoomu
could you accept that invite I just sent?
where can I see that?
<@U0Y4ZF0QM|mitchell> has joined the channel
ramesh: in your gmail
ok
ramesh: great. now go back to that review page
ok
you should see more options - -2 to +2 on review, -1 to +1 on verify still
I still see -1 to +1 on both
very confusing.
you’re in the “owner” group which should give you superpowers
ok. I am checking for the above link.. <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/19/>
when I use my account which has the same groups as you, I see this:
let me make sure my test account has no super powers
ok
ramesh: I just created a new account and logged in, I see -2 to +2. <@U0KM61BCP>: what do you see?
ramesh: could you refresh without cache?
doing that.
I only see -1 0 +1
ah, cbf, did you accept the invite I sent to your ibm address?
hmmm checking
No I have
Now I have
the answer is no, I see it is still pending
now you’re in.
yes
cbf: please refresh with no cache and tell me what you see
same

<@U0UHG4VP1|ry> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ry/F1BEVMSQK/Try_something_like_this_once_you___ve_checked_out_the_repo.txt|Try something like this once you’ve checked out the repo>

file.name: Try_something_like_this_once_you___ve_checked_out_the_repo.txt
file.title: Try something like this once you’ve checked out the repo
file.preview:
Rys-iMac:lf-sandbox ry$ git status
HEAD is now at 7e7ddeb Initial empty repository
Rys-iMac:lf-sandbox ry$ echo > merge.txt
Rys-iMac:lf-sandbox ry$ git add merge.txt 
Rys-iMac:lf-sandbox ry$ git commit -a -s -m "Test of things"
file.preview_highlight:
Rys-iMac:lf-sandbox ry$ git status
HEAD is now at 7e7ddeb Initial empty repository
Rys-iMac:lf-sandbox ry$ echo > merge.txt
Rys-iMac:lf-sandbox ry$ git add merge.txt 
Rys-iMac:lf-sandbox ry$ git commit -a -s -m "Test of things"

text: so now that ramesh and cbf have the ability to merge - feel free to push up a change on your own and review
working now
you should also have the ability to abandon my change, merge it, etc
you should be able to edit my commit message as well
ramesh: go here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/19/1> and remove my vote (you should see an X next to my name)
feel free to create new branches, etc, if you want to play with cherry pick and rebase.
which repo I have to checkout?
the UI here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/19/1> shows “lf-sandbox” in the project field. that is the one you need.
plus, it’s the only project that isn’t read-only
go here when logged in:
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/admin/projects/lf-sandbox>
then click ssh, with the commit hook, copy paste and run it somewhere you can throw away
if you are cloning via https, which you should not do, but if you are, go here: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/settings/http-password> and generate your http password
<@U0N13GKRP|zaki> has joined the channel
